description: Demolition of existing buildings and redevelopment of site to provide nine new dwellinghouses with associated boundary treatment, amenity space, refuse stores and cycle provisions along with associated parking
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: This is required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990.

Prior to any above groundworks (excluding demolition) of the development hereby permitted details of the energy saving strategy to include photovoltaics (PV) shall be submitted to and agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The development shall be completed in accordance with the approved details.Reason: In the interests of sustainability and energy conservation in accordance with Policies 5.2 (Minimising Carbon Dioxide Emissions) and 5.3 (Sustainable Design & Construction) of the London Plan (July 2011) and Policy DM1 (Sustainable Design and Construction Standards) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.][EP1]

Full details of the materials, colour and texture of the external finish of the building shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority before development commences and the development shall be constructed in accordance with the approved finishes.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any above groundworks (excluding demolition) of the development hereby permitted and notwithstanding the details shown on the approved plans stated in condition 1 of this permission, the following details shall have been submitted (on plans at a scale of no less than 1:20 and 1:5) and approved by the Local Planning Authority.- Window reveals, door reveals, overhangs, rainwater goods.The development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved details.Reason: It is necessary to provide these details as it is integral to the design and appearance of the building and therefore agreement of these details prior to commencement would ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

All works on site shall take place in accordance with the following details which shall have previously been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority prior to the commencement of work:(a) Provision for loading/unloading materials.(b) Storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles.(c) Temporary site access.(d) Signing system for works traffic.(e) Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise andabatement of other nuisance arising from development works.(f) Location of all ancillary site buildings.(g) Measures to protect any trees, shrubbery and other landscapefeatures to be retained on the site during the course of development.(h) Means of enclosure of the site.(i) Wheel washing equipment.(j) The parking of vehicles of the site operatives and visitors(k) The erection and maintenance of security hoarding.(l) Hours of construction and deliveriesReason: This information is required prior to the commencement of the development in order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to occupation of the development hereby permitted details of secure cycle parking facilities for the occupants of, and visitors to, shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority and shall be fully implemented and shall thereafter be retained for use at all times.Reason: To ensure the provision of satisfactory cycle storage facilities and in the interests of highway safety in accordance with Policy DM8 (Sustainable Transport for New Developments) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Refuse storage facilities and recycling facilities shall be provided prior to the occupation of the development hereby permitted in accordance with details which shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority prior to the occupation of the development, such facilities to be permanently retained at the site.Reason: To ensure the provision of refuse facilities to the satisfaction of the Council in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Within 3 months of first occupation, evidence must be submitted to the Council confirming that the development hereby approved has achieved not less than the CO2 reductions (ENE1), internal water usage (WAT1) standards equivalent to Code for Sustainable Homes level 4. Evidence requirements are detailed in the "Schedule of evidence Required for Post Construction Stage from Ene1 & Wat1 of the Code for Sustainable Homes Technical Guide. Evidence to demonstrate a 19% reduction compared to 2013 part L regulations and internal water usage rates of 105l/p/ day must be submitted to and approved by the Local Planning Authority, unless otherwise agreed in writing.Reason: In the interests of sustainability and energy conservation in accordance with Policies 5.2 (Minimising Carbon Dioxide Emissions) and 5.3 (Sustainable Design & Construction) of the London Plan (2016) and Policy DM1 (Sustainable Design and Construction Standards) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of Part 1 of Schedule 2 of the Town & Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order, 2015 (as amended) (or any Order revoking or re-enacting this Order) no extensions (including porches or dormer windows) to the dwelling houses or buildings shall be erected within the curtilage.Reason: To safeguard the privacy and amenity of adjoining occupiers, maintain adequate amenity space and safeguard the cohesive appearance of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Fences, walls or other means of enclosure shall be erected along the boundaries of the site prior to the occupation of the dwellinghouses to which they relate, in accordance with details which shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority and shall thereafter be permanently retained.Reason: In order to ensure the privacy of adjoining occupiers and visual amenity of the area is retained in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (or any Order revoking or re-enacting this Order) no windows or other openings (other than those hereby approved) shall be formed in the elevations and roof above ground floor level of the building hereby approved without the prior written consent of the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the occupiers of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The development hereby permitted shall be carried out in accordance with the approved Ecological Report prepared by AAe Environmental Consultants dated 23 December 2019.Reason: To safeguard and protect the sites biodiversity and nature conservation value in accordance with Policy DM6 (Biodiversity) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No demolition, site clearance or building operations shall be commenced until tree protection to the standards set out in BS5837: 2005 "Protection of Trees on Construction Sites" (figures 4 and 5) has been erected around the trees shown on the approved drawings as being retained on the site. The fencing is to be not less than 1.5 metres in height and shall encloseeither:-(a) the area described by the limit set out in Table 1 or(b) a radius as set out in Figure 2 of BS 5837: 2005, or alternatively(c) such an area as may have previously been approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.Such tree protection shall be maintained during the course of development, and no storage, site structures, parking or any other operation shall be permitted within the area thereby protected. Within the protected area:(a) levels shall not be raised or lowered in relation to the existingground level,(b) no roots shall be cut, trenches dug, or soil removed or drains andservices laid,(c) no buildings, site huts, roads or other engineering operations shallbe constructed or carried out,(d) no vehicles shall be driven over the area,(e) no materials or equipment shall be stored.and the destruction by burning of any materials shall not take place on the site or adjoining land unless the fires are at a minimum distance from the protected area of 6.00 metres.Reason: To prevent unnecessary damage occurring to the trees during building operations, thereby safeguarding the visual amenities of the site in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to occupation of the development a landscaping scheme including the detail of the removal of any trees shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved scheme shall be implemented within the first planting season following completion of the development and the tree planting and landscaping shall thereafter be maintained for five years to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority. Any trees or shrubs which die during this period shall be replaced in the first available planting season, and the area shown to be landscaped shall be permanently retained for that purpose only.Reason: In the interests of visual amenity and also that the Local Planning Authority shall be satisfied as to the details of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The removal of all trees on site and in particular the Oak Tree (T40) shall proceed with a precautionary approach as outlined in the letter prepared by AAe consultants 26th June 2020.Reason: In order to protect any protected bat species and accord with policy DM6 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy April 2012.

Prior to the occupation of the development the applicant shall install Bat and Bird boxes in accordance with a scheme which has previously been submitted to and approved by the LPA, which shall thereafter be maintained in perpetuity.Reason: In order to protect the biodiversity of the site and accord with policy DM6 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy April 2012.

Prior to the occupation of the development the applicant shall only erect close boarded fences where these are raised by 150-200mm above ground level to enable ecological connectivity for species, such as hedgehogs. The close boarded fences shall be maintained in perpetuity at that height above ground level.Reason: In order to protect the biodiversity of the site and accord with policy DM6 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy April 2012.

No external lighting shall be installed without approval from the local planning authority. Any proposed external lighting shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local prior to installation. Any approved lighting shall be installed inaccordance with the approved details which shall follow bat conservation trust guidelines. The lighting shall thereafter be maintained in accordance with approved details.Reason: In order to protect the biodiversity of the site and accord with policy DM6 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy April 2012.

Prior to the occupation of the development hereby approved details of the provision of 9 ECP shall have been submitted to and approved by the Local Planning Authority. The ECP shall be provided before occupation and retained thereafter.Reason: In the interests of air quality improvements and to encourage the uptake of Electric Vehicles.

Prior to any above ground level works, details shall have been submitted to confirm that the five identified wheelchair housing units meet the Building Regulation requirement M4(3). The units shall be built and maintained in accordance with the approved M4(3)specifications. All other units shall be built to meet Building Regulation requirement M4(2) 'accessible and adaptable dwellings'.Reason: To ensure that the development provides a range of homes to meet different needs and to ensure compliance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012, and Policies 3.5 and 3.8 Policy 3.8 of the London Plan 2016.

Notwithstanding the details for the development hereby permitted and prior to the commencement of any above groundworks (excluding demolition) a landscaping and parking plan detailing a maximum of 2 car parking spacesper dwelling (including any within the garage) shall be submitted to and approved by the Local Planning Authority and the development built out in accordance with the approved plans.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate off-street parking accommodation and to avoid the congestion of surrounding roads by parked vehicles in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to any above groundworks (excluding demolition) of the development hereby permitted details of the energy saving strategy to include photovoltaics (PV) shall be submitted to and agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The development shall be completed in accordance with the approved details.Reason: In the interests of sustainability and energy conservation in accordance with Policies 5.2 (Minimising Carbon Dioxide Emissions) and 5.3 (Sustainable Design & Construction) of the London Plan (July 2011) and Policy DM1 (Sustainable Design and Construction Standards) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.][EP1]

Consultation ResponsesFlood Risk & Drainage Officer: No comments receivedNeighbourhood Traffic Engineer: No comments received.Site and SurroundingsThe application site comprises a four storey building known as Hanover House, situated on the west side of the High Street, New Malden. The building appears to be commercial at the ground floor level with residential accommodation above.The application site is located within New Malden District Centre. The site has a Public Transport Accessibility Level (PTAL) of 4 (good).ProposalErection of single storey rear, first floor rear extension above the existing flat roof of the commercial unit below to create 1 no 2-bed flat which will be accessed via a new stair enclosure at the rear. Erection of rear extension in existing building to convert existing first floor 1-bed flat into 2-bed flat which will continue to be accessed from the entrance doorway on New Malden High Street.Relevant HistoryA number of recent planning permission and advertisement consents have been granted in relation to the ground floor commercial unit. Regarding the residential accommodation above, the following planning permissions are most relevant:21/03870/FUL - Erection of single storey rear extensions at first floor level above the existing flat roof of commercial unit below to create 2no.x new studio flats, which will be accessed via new stair enclosure at rear. - Refused 03.03.202298/4176/FUL - Conversion of existing third floor flat to 2 self contained studio flats with elevational alterations - Granted 10/11/199898/4071/FUL - Conversion of offices on first and second floors 2 one bedroom and 2 two bedroom flats, alterations to third floor to form 2 bedroom flat and elevational alterations - Granted 01/12/1998AssessmentPrinciple of DevelopmentPolicy CS10 of the Core Strategy seeks to increase housing delivery within the borough. The proposal provides for 2 x studio flats and the conversion of an existing 1 bedroom flat into a 2 bedroom flat. The provision of additional housing is considered to be acceptable in principle. It should be noted that currently the Council is unable to demonstrate a five year supply of deliverable housing sites. As such, paragraph 11 of the NPPF stipulates that planning permission should be granted unless (i) the application of policies in this Framework that protect areas or assets of particular importance provides a clear reason for refusing the development proposed; or (ii) any adverse impacts of doing so significantly and demonstrably outweigh the benefits, when assessed against policies in this Framework taken as a whole. Whilst it is recognised that the Council does not have an up-to-date supply of housing sites, the benefits of the proposed development would need to be weighed against any significant adverse impact, as  required by paragraph 11 of the NPPF. The planning balance assessment will form the last section of this report.Agent of ChangePolicy D13 (Agent of Change) of the London Plan (2021) sets out that development should be designed to ensure that established noise and other nuisance-generating uses remain viable and can continue or grow without unreasonable restrictions being placed on them. Development proposals should manage noise and other potential nuisances by: ensuring good design mitigates and minimises existing and potential nuisances generated by existing uses and activities located in the area exploring mitigation measures early in the design stage, with necessary and appropriate provisions including ongoing and future management of mitigation measures secured through planning obligations separating new noise-sensitive development where possible from existing noise-generating businesses and uses through distance, screening, internal layout, sound-proofing, insulation and other acoustic design measuresPolicy D13 sets out that: 'Boroughs should not normally permit development proposals that have not clearly demonstrated how noise and other nuisances will be mitigated and managed.'It is noted that the ground floor of the site is in commercial use, along with adjoining Dawson House and neighbouring buildings also. There also appears to be a number of air conditioning units, plant and other equipment in close proximity to the boundary of the application site. The existing servicing area for the ground floor commercial unit would be retained and would be directly beneath the proposed balconies.The second reason for refusal of application ref: 21/03870/FUL is as follows:Insufficient information has been submitted to demonstrate that the proposed dwellings would not prejudice the ongoing viability of neighbouring businesses and would not result in unreasonable restrictions being placed on them, contrary to Policy D13 of the London Plan (2021) and the NPPF (2021).In response to this reason for the refusal the applicant has amended the scheme to remove a balcony from the rear elevation and glazing has been changed from full height doors to casement windows. A fixed planter below the window cill has been incorporated for noise attenuation purposes and it is stated that mitigations such as sound insulation and sound dampening laminate would be incorporated.As with the previous refusal, no Noise Assessment or other evidence has been submitted to demonstrate that the proposed flats would not prejudice the ongoing operation of neighbouring businesses without unreasonable restrictions being placed on them. No technical details of the proposed noise mitigations have been submitted and the proposed habitable room windows would nevertheless in close proximity to plant, equipment and the shared boundaries with neighbouring businesses. It is noted that one of the areas previously indicated to be servicing/parking for the ground floor commercial unit would be converted to car parking for the proposed flat. It is unclear whether the reduction in servicing areas would adversely impact the ongoing operation of the business. The proposal therefore fails in this regard.Character & DesignPolicy D3 (Optimising Site Capacity Through the Design-Led Approach) of the London Plan (2021) sets out that all development must make the best use of land by following a design-led approach that optimises the capacity of sites. Policy DM10 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012) setes out that: "Development proposals will be required to incorporate principles of good design.Along the southern shared boundary, the first floor rear extension would be approximately 13.6m in depth, have a maximum height of 7.3m (when measured from ground floor level) or approximately 3.2m from the first floor level to the roof. The proposed extensions would span the width of the property at the rear elevation (approximately 10.9m) with a flat roof form. The proposals include an enclosed terrace of approximately 20sqm in size which would abut the northern site boundary. The terrace would be accessible to the extended 2x bedroom flat only.The proposed first floor rear extensions would be situated to the rear of Hanover House and would not be visible from High Street. The proposed development would have a bulky and blocky appearance when viewed from Sussex Place to the rear, however, it would be of a similar appearance to adjoining Dawson House and would therefore not have any significant adverse impact on the character of the area.While the proposal would not enhance the character and appearance of the area, it is noted that development off Sussex Place is piecemeal and comprises a mixture of residential and commercial uses. Within this context, it is considered that the proposal development would be of an acceptable appearance. Standard of AccommodationPolicy D6 (Housing Quality and Standards) of the London Plan (2021) sets out that housing development should be of high quality design and provide adequately sized rooms (as set out in Table 3.1 of the London Plan 2021) with comfortable and functional layouts which are fit for purpose and meet the needs of Londoners without differentiating between tenures.Policy D6 of the London Plan (2021) encourages housing developments to maximise the provision of dual aspect dwellings and normally avoid the provision of single aspect dwellings. Single aspect dwellings should only be provided where it is considered a more appropriate design solution to meet the requirements of Part B of Policy D3 of the London Plan (2021).The first reason for refusal of application ref: 21/03870/FUL is as follows: It has not been demonstrated through the submission of cogent evidence that the proposed dwellings would receive sufficient levels of daylight and sunlight and would not be subject to unacceptable levels of noise. The proposed flats would have a poor quality outlook and would have insufficient amenity space. The proposed units would therefore be of a poor standard of accommodation contrary to Policies DM10 and DM11 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012), Policy D6 of the London Plan (2021), the Kingston Residential Design SPD (2013) and the NPPF (2021). In terms of amendments, the applicant has incorporated a larger terrace for the extended flat while the proposed additional flat would have a new terrace of 5.4m2 in size and a larger rear terrace which would be partly recessed.No Daylight & Sunlight Assessment has been submitted. While it is noted that the additional terrace areas would provide additional aspect, it is considered that the proposed flats would remain heavily reliant on neighbouring properties for their outlook. The outlook for the extended flat would be onto the 4.2m deep terrace with the proposed additional flat beyond. As it stands, significant concerns remain as to the levels of daylight, sunlight and quality of outlook. As is noted in the 'Agent of Change' section above, no Noise Assessment or other evidence has been submitted to demonstrate that noise levels for the proposed flats would be acceptable, given the close proximity of commercial uses below and adjoining the site.Both flats would meet or exceed the minimum space standards in relation to Gross Internal Area (GIA) and each would be provided with at least 10sqm of private amenity space in the form of roof terraces. The proposed extensions would provide 2.5m floor to ceiling height.  It is unclear what levels of daylight or direct sunlight (if any) the proposed terraces would receive.Overall, it has not been demonstrated that the proposed flat and extended flat would receive adequate levels of daylight, sunlight and would not be subject to unacceptable levels of noise from neighbouring businesses. Furthermore, the extended flat would have an especially poor quality of outlook. Officers are unable to conclude that the proposed development would provide a good standard of accommodation for occupants. The first reason for refusal has not been addressed.Unit MixPolicy DM13 of the Council's LDF Core Strategy, 2012 states that the Council will ensure that the housing delivered is of high quality and the most appropriate type.  The Policy also states that new residential development is expected to incorporate a mix of unit sizes and types.  The Policy requires that 30% of the proposed units should be 3 or more bedrooms (which are capable of family occupation) unless it can be robustly demonstrated that this would be unsuitable or unviable. The fourth reason for refusal is as follows:The proposed development would fail to incorporate a mix of unit sizes and would fail to provide any 3 or more bedroom units and it has not been demonstrated that the provision of 3 or more bedroom units would be unviable, contrary to Policy DM13 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012).The previous proposal was for 2 studio flats and the extension of the existing 1 bedroom flat to turn it into a 2 bedroom flat. The current proposal is for 2x 2 bedroom flats (1 additional and 1 by way of extensions to an existing flat).Within the above context, it is considered that the proposed development would provide a more appropriate unit mix. The fourth reason for refusal has been addressed.Impact on Neighbouring Residential AmenityThere appears to be residential accommodation at the first and second floor levels at Nos. 121 and 123 High Street to the north of the application site. However, any loss of daylight/sunlight and undue sense of enclosure would primarily affect what appear to be larger roof terraces at the rear. It is therefore unlikely that any adverse impact would be significant. While there would appear to be residential accommodation at the adjoining property Dawson House, there do not appear to be any habitable room windows which would be directly affected by the proposals. While there would be some loss of privacy to flats to the west at Charnwood Close, this impact would be minor as it would be largely onto communal areas/accessways.Overall, it is considered that the proposal would not have any significant adverse impact on the amenities of neighbours.Highways & Parking The proposed flats would not have any on-site car parking and the site is not located within a CPZ. The site is located within a PTAL 4 with good accessibility to public transport links. Subject to the proposed development being secured by legal agreement as 'car-free', that is precluding residents of the proposed flats applying for on-street car parking permits, in the event that a CPZ is brought into effect, it is considered that the proposal would be acceptable in terms of car parking provision. The third reason for refusal is as follows:It has not been demonstrated that there would be sufficient space on site to accommodate a secure cycle store and a waste and recycling store given the area to the rear is indicated as being in use for the servicing of the ground floor commercial unit, contrary to Policies DM8 and DM10 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012) and Policy T5 of the London Plan (2021).The revised proposals include 1x car parking space for the use of the proposed flat. The proposed car parking space would be situated partially underneath the rear balcony in the area to front of the access to the stairwell.Scaling off the submitted drawings and the area identified for car parking would be unable to provide a policy compliant car parking space (2.4m x 4.8m). No details have been submitted of secure cycle parking. A 140l bin store has been indicated adjacent to the car parking space. Insufficient information has been submitted to demonstrate that there would be sufficient space for separate recycling, municipal and food waste receptacles. Given the above, the proposed ground floor layout is likely to adversely impact pedestrian access to the proposed flat.Overall, insufficient information has been submitted to demonstrate that there would be sufficient space on site to accommodate a secure cycle store and a waste and recycling store. The proposed car parking space would not meet the minimum size requirements and is likely to obstruct access to the flat and to oversail the road to the rear and potentially obstruct and inconvenience other highway users.Planning Balance/ConclusionThe proposal would provide a net increase of 1x Class C3 unit of accommodation and a total of 2x 2 bedroom flats on site; this would make a positive, albeit modest, contribution toward meeting the Council's housing targets.However the proposed flats would fail to provide a good standard of accommodation, it has not been demonstrated that the proposed flats would not prejudice the ongoing development of neighbouring businesses and  it has not been demonstrated that on-site secure cycle parking and waste storage could be accommodated for the proposed flat.Overall, it is considered that the adverse impacts identified above would significantly and demonstrably outweigh the benefits of the scheme. It is therefore recommended that planning permission is refused.

The design information shall include details of the proposed external appearance including external materials and colour finish. The applicant is informed that the submitted details have been assessed by relevant consultants and are hereby approved subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the approved details, in relation to Conditions 5 (Secure Cycle Parking) and 6 (Fire Safety) of planning permission 22/01850/HOU, which states:Conditions 5 (Secure Cycle Parking) - Prior to beneficial occupation, details of secure cycle parking facilities to serve the development to which this permission relates shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.The cycle parking facilities as shown in the approved details shall be provided prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates and shall be permanently retained for that purpose and kept free from obstruction thereafter.Reason: To ensure that appropriate opportunities to promote sustainable transport are taken up, in accordance with policy T5 of the London Plan 2021 and policies CS6 and DM8 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.Conditions 6 (Fire Safety) - Prior to any above ground works (excluding demolition) a Fire Safety Strategy shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The Fire Safety Strategy shall demonstrate how the development will achieve the highest standards of fire safety and shall include the following details:1) suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point;2) Appropriate fire alarm systems;3) Passive and active fire safety measures;4) appropriate construction details to minimise the risk of fire spread;5) provision of suitable and convenient means of escape/ an evacuation strategy;6) provision of suitable access and equipment for firefighting which is appropriate for the size and use of the development. The Fire Safety Strategy shall include a statement of competence.The development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved Strategy and thereafter maintained.Reason: In the interests of fire safety and to ensure the safety of all building users in accordance with Policy D12 (Fire safety) of the London Plan 2021

Application SiteThe application relates to the Marks and Spencer store, specifically the rear access onto Eden Walk. The application site falls within the Primary Shopping Area and is a secondary shopping frontage. ProposalDisplay of 1 no externally illuminated fascia sign.Consultation48 surrounding properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received.The key areas of assessment are:- The impact of the development on character and appearance; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings, and,- The impact of the development on the highways. Character and appearanceThe proposed replacement signage is considered to be appropriate in relation to the host premises and its commercial character and the surrounding area. It would not lead to a proliferation of signage or visual clutter within the streetscene. It would be acceptable in terms of scale, form and design and there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposal, thereby complying with Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012. Neighbouring AmenitiesGiven that the proposed signage is located within a retail area, it is considered that there would be no significant impact upon the amenity of any neighbouring properties. Highway SafetyThe application site is located in a pedestrianised zone and therefore the lighting is not considered to result in any significant impact upon vehicular safety. The proposed illumination levels of the signage of 800cd/m2 would be appropriate in the site context. As such, Officers consider that the proposal would comply with Policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy, 2012.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

The site comprises a detached dwelling.17 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and 2 objections have been received relating to:- Effects on trees- Excessive height or bulk of buildings- Inappropriate design/layout- Loss of light/Sunlight- PrivacyOfficers note that the current application would not impact on any existing trees. The remaining concerns raised will be taken into consideration during the assessment of the application and detailed below.The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and, - Fire Safety Assessment.DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed two storey side/rear infill extension would adhere to the recommendations set out in the Residential Design SPD, and as such is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. The proposed first floor rear extension would not strictly comply with the recommendations set out in the Residential Design SPD, in regards to set in from the shared boundaries, however it would have a modest depth and as such would appear a subordinate addition to the host property.Officers note that the proposed piggyback extension would be appropriately set back from the front elevation and would extend no more than 1.3m in height, however it would be separated from the neighbouring properties by more than 2.1m on one side. While this is not recommended by the Residential Design SPD, it is not considered that the host property has a prominent position within the streetscene, and as such it is not considered that the proposed development would appear incongruous within the streetscene. In any case, it would appear an appropriate and proportionate addition to the host property. AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Officers note that the proposed development would extend closer to the shared boundary with 102 Kings Road and would extend further in depth than the neighbouring property's existing rear elevation. While this is the case, officers note that the proposal would pass the 45-degree plan test in relation to the closest habitable window at ground and first floor level, and as such would not result in a loss of light/sunlight. Further given that 102 Kings Road sits within a wider plot than the surrounding properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not appear overbearing.On the boundary with 106 Kings Road, the proposed developments would have a modest depth and as such it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance or loss of light.While additional openings are proposed to the rear elevation, officers consider that it would not offer dissimilar views to what is existing on the host property or properties within the immediate vicinity. However, it is noted that openings would be proposed at roof level on the side elevations, and given the close proximity to neighbouring properties, it is considered appropriate to impose a condition to ensure these openings are obscure glazed and non-opening below 1.7m above finished floor levels. Therefore, It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. Fire Safety AssessmentLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer Comment:  The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy.  Officers are satisfied that the proposal adequately meets the requirements of Policy D12(A). Ongoing compliance with the strategy would be secured through conditions, in the event of a favourable recommendation. In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Application SiteThe application site is located on the northern side of the Griffin Centre which is immediately west of Market Place in the designated Kingston Town Centre.The surrounding area is an area of mixed use. The site is located within the designated Kingston Old Town Conservation Area and the unit has a statutory listing (Grade II) as part of the group of buildings that form the Griffin Centre.The Historic England Listing description is set out below:"Chiesman's Store (formerly Hide's Store). A large modern department store, most of which is not of interest, but it contains some items of importance. In the basement, some flint walling and C17 brickwork. Inside the store, a fine mid C17 timber staircase from the Castle Hotel, which formerly occupied the site. Heavy square newels with carved, panelled sides and ball finials; strings carved with laurel leaves; heavy, moulded handrails; the space between handrails and strings filled with heavy foliage and roses, within which are some human figures. Some of the newels are initialled. [VCH]. Also incorporated into the new structure is a C18 hipped, tiled roof above a much-altered 3 storey, 4 bay range. [On the south side facing alleyway to back yard]. Listed solely for the items described."ProposalThe application seeks retrospective advertisement consent for the display of 13no's hand-painted fascia signs, 1no. non-illuminated projecting sign, 2no. illuminated menu boxes and 2no. hand-painted stall-riser signs. An accompanying Listed Building Consent and Full Planning application have been submitted for the same proposals (plus other shopfront alterations) under reference: 22/02718/LBC and 22/02669/FUL.CONSULTATIONS23no. surrounding owner/occupiers were notified of the application.  No responses were received.   Kingston Town Centre Conservation Area Advisory Committee: No objection.Historic England: No view expressed on the proposal. Authorise delegated determination.ASSESSMENTThe main issue to assess in the consideration of this application is the impact that the development would have on the character of the area and the streetscene and impact upon heritage assets and impact upon highway safety.Character and AppearanceParagraph 125 of the NPPF 2021 states that the creation of high quality, beautiful and sustainable buildings and places is fundamental to what the planning and development process should achieve. Good design is a key aspect of sustainable development, creates better places in which to live and work and helps to make development acceptable to communities.Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policy CS8 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 states the Council's intention to protect the primarily suburban character of the Borough, its existing buildings and areas of high quality and historic interest from inappropriate development. The Council will seek opportunities for sensitive enhancement in these areas and in areas of poorer environmental quality, where character has been eroded or needs improving. The assessment of development proposals will be guided by the Borough Character Study 2011 and the Residential Design SPD 2013, ensuring that new development:-	Recognises distinctive local features and character;-	Has regard to the historic and natural environment;-	Helps enhance locally distinctive places of high architectural and urban design quality;-	Accords with neighbourhood "strategies for delivery" set out under "Character, Design and Heritage"; and,-	Relates well and connects to its surroundings.Policy DM10 identifies the most essential elements in contributing to the character and local distinctiveness of a street or area which should be respected, maintained or enhanced. These include:-	Prevailing development typology, including housing types, sizes and occupancy;-	Prevailing density of the surrounding area;-	Scale, layout, height, form (including roof forms) and massing;-	Landscape setting and features;-	Plot width and format, which includes spaces between buildings;-	Building line build-up, set-back and front boundary; and,-	Typical details and key features such as roof forms, window format, building materials and design detailing of elevations, existence of grass verges, etc.The proposed works consist of the installation of new advertising signage. Two illuminated rectangular menu boards are proposed either side of the entrance door fronting Market Place, one non-illuminated projecting sign to be installed on the pre-existing bracket and 13no. hand-painted signs to the Market Place and Griffin Arcade elevations.Overall, the design and materials are considered to be visually unobtrusive and are considered to both respect and be in keeping with the host building and the surrounding streetscene, thereby complying with Policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy, 2012.Impact upon Heritage AssetsSections 16 and 66 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) state that in considering whether to grant planning permission for development which affects a listed building or its setting, the local planning authority shall have special regard to the desirability of preserving the building or its setting or any features of special architectural or historic interest which it possesses.Section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.Paragraphs 199 to 208 of the NPPF 2021 set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.When considering the impact of a proposed development on the significance of a designated heritage asset, great weight should be given to the asset's conservation (and the more important the asset, the greater the weight should be). This is irrespective of whether any potential harm amounts to substantial harm, total loss or less than substantial harm to its significance.The proposals are considered to be sympathetic to the scale, mass, height and aesthetic attributes of the designated heritage asset of the Grade-II listed building. The level of intervention on the fabric of the Grade II building itself is minimal, thereby preserving the character defining elements of the historic fabric, retaining the authenticity of the building. The impact of the proposals is considered to result in "less than substantial harm" to the heritage asset. Highway SafetyThe NPPF requires that in assessing applications for development, it is ensured that: appropriate opportunities to promote sustainable transport modes can be - or have been - taken up; safe and suitable access to the site can be achieved for all users; and any significant impacts from the development on the transport network (in terms of capacity and congestion), or on highway safety, can be cost effectively mitigated to an acceptable degree. Development should only be prevented or refused on highways grounds if there would be an unacceptable impact on highway safety, or the residual cumulative impacts on the road network would be severe. Local Planning Authorities are expected to have regard to its effect upon the safe use and operation of any form of traffic or transport on land (including the safety of pedestrians), on or over water, or in the air. Public safety considerations, the second arm of control over advertisements, do not arise very frequently. However, when it can be shown that signs would be confused with traffic signals or the visibility of drivers is impaired, a solid and sustainable ground for refusal of Advertisement Regulation consent is provided. Most of the signage would not be illuminated, however the two rectangular blackened steel finished menu boards either side of the entrance door would be static internally illuminated to a level of 50cd/m2. In addition, the fascia sign is externally static illuminated to a level of 500cd/m2. It is considered given the level of illuminance and position of the building in a pedestrianised zone of the town centre, that it would not result in a distraction to highway users and would not prejudice highway safety. The proposed signage is therefore in accordance with Policy DM10 of the Core Strategy. Conclusion The proposed development would provide for the display of advertisements to Unit 2, The Griffin Centre, Kingston. It is considered that the proposed signage is acceptable resulting in no harm to the character and appearance of the building or wider conservation area. The proposals would not have any material effect on highway safety. The proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan and there are no other material considerations which otherwise indicate that advertisement consent should be refused. Therefore, it is recommended that advertisement consent be granted. Recommendation That advertisement consent should be GRANTED.

Application SiteThe site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.ProposalErection of single-storey side, rear and front extension with installation of garage doors. Second floor side extension. Hip to gable and rear dormer roof extension with installation of 2no front and 1no side rooflights to facilitate loft conversion.Consultation21 Neighbouring properties have been notified and 2 objections from 1 address have been received stating;- Excessive height or bulk of buildings- Loss of light/Sunlight- Privacy- Inappropriate design/layoutOfficers will consider these comments alongside their assessment.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- Fire safetyDesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: Officers note that several properties along Alexandra Drive benefit from 2 storey side extensions. Policy Guidance 36 of the residential design SPD states that On semi-detached properties proposed side extensions should- respect the symmetry of the adjoining semi-detached property;- not exceed 50% the width of the original house;- be set in from the boundary by at least 1m to maintain the existing gaps between properties and the rhythm of gaps;- The roof line should be set down from that of the original house by a minimum of 500mm; and,- The front elevation should be set-back by at least 500mm from the front of the house.  Officers acknowledge that the proposed hip to gable addition will result in loss of symmetry between the properties. It is also acknowledged that this is a common feature within the street scene and numerous properties have hip to gable extensions that were  constructed under permitted development.The proposed side extension would be less than half the width, set in at first floor from the boundary to maintain a gap and set down from the original roofline in compliance with the guidance. The proposed development is therefore considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  With regards to neighbouring amenity, The principal properties to be considered are No. 93 and No. 97 Alexandra Drive. With regards to No. 97, the proposed rear extension would extend approximately 4.8m from the existing rear elevation with proposed eaves height of 2.8m. This rear extension would in fill the area between No. 97 and the existing outrigger. Although officers note that the depth could be considered excessive, it is also noted that deeper extension has been permitted along Alexandra Drive and due to the limited eaves height at 2.8m and pitched roof, the proposed extension would be compliant with BRE Guidance in relation to daylight sunlight. With regards to No. 93, due to the existing situation and the existing adjoining garages, it is considered that the proposed rear extension would not lead to loss of light or an overbearing apperance. In relation to the proposed side extension, due to the set in at first floor level coupled with the large existing gap between the two properties, it is not considered the proposed development would adversely effect No. 93. Officers note the proposed side extension would have obscured glazed windows. This would be secured by condition should permission be granted to ensure privacy is maintained. Overall, It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Fire Safety London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.10 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- Fire SafetyWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: The proposed dormer and hip-to-gable extension would not generally comply with the guidance in the Residential Design SPD (Dormer Windows) but could be constructed under permitted development. In addition, in the context of other houses in the street or wider area, this form of construction would not be unusual.The proposed rear extension and garage conversion combined with the existing rear extension granted under planning permission ref: 29495 would have a total depth of over 6.5m, falling outside Policy guidance 33 of the Residential Design SPD. Although officers acknowledge the proposed development would only be slightly visible from the streetscene (only it would be visible from the gardens of neighbouring properties), the width of the proposed rear extension and garage conversion combined would be an unacceptable addition to an already over developed area. In addition, the proposed rear extension would not appear proportionate or subordinate to the host building, as it would be of similar depth and width as the original dwelling when considering planning permission ref: 29495. Therefore, overall, the proposed development is considered to be unacceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, massing and spacing. It is considered that there would be adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: Given the siting of the proposed development in relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A). For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would not be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).
